channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Narendra Modi Exhorts Small Businesses to Embrace Competition
item.description: In his first extensive comments on national economic policy, the opposition candidate for prime minister revealed a shift in his stance on the modern retail marketplace in a country known for its protectionist measures.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, the prime ministerial candidate of the Bharatiya Janata Party, addressing the Confederation of All India Traders in New Delhi on Thursday.

item.title: Armed Standoff in Crimea as Ex-President Looks to Russia
item.description: Masked gunmen believed to be pro-Russian seized the Crimean Parliament on Thursday, and just hours later Viktor F. Yanukovych, the ousted president of Ukraine, appealed to Russia to protect his safety.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Merkel Warns Britain Not to Expect Too Much
item.description: The German leader addressed both houses of Parliament and sought to tamp down British expectations of support for fundamental change in Europe.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE, KATRIN BENNHOLD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Hagel Warns Russia Not to Intervene in Ukraine
item.description: At a NATO meeting, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel and other defense ministers offered support for the new leadership in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Videogame Uses Japanese War Criminals as Targets
item.description: The game launched by People’s Daily Online Weibo, a microblog affiliated with the newspaper of the ruling Chinese Communist Party, is titled “Shoot the Devils.”
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The targets are the 14 convicted Class A war criminals honored at the Yasukuni Shrine in Japan.

item.title: Gunmen Seize Government Buildings in Crimea
item.description: Activists believed to be pro-Russian made no immediate demands but their actions added to the tension in the ethnically and politically divided eastern region of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rival protesters clashed in Simferopol, Crimea’s regional capital.

item.title: India Ink: For Teenage Girls, Video Takes Fear Out of a Shunned Topic
item.description: “Mythri,” an animated video that teaches girls about their changing bodies, has found success in schools in the Indian state of Karnataka and is set to expand to the rest of the country.
item.dc:creator: By KAVITHA RAO
item.media:description: With the animated video "Mythri," female students in the Indian state of Karnataka being taught not to be embarrassed by their changing bodies.

item.title: India Ink: A Look at India Through the Eyes of Its Visitors
item.description: The new book “A Strange Kind of Paradise” explores how travelers through the ages – from Alexander the Great to Steve Jobs — have experienced India.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By AAYUSH SONI
item.media:description: The cover of the book "A Strange Kind of Paradise: India Through Foreign Eyes," by the former BBC journalist Sam Miller.

item.title: Departing U.S. Envoy to China Praises Growing Economic Ties
item.description: The United States ambassador Gary F. Locke said the countries’ economic relationship was a “steadying influence” but said Beijing needed to make progress on legal and human rights issues.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: North Korea Displays Another Captured Missionary
item.description: A South Korean man said in a staged news conference that he was working for South Korean intelligence and called himself a “criminal.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: In Ukraine, Naming of Interim Government Gets Mixed Response
item.description: As the names of the proposed ministers were read in Independence Square in Kiev, it became clear just how completely the ordinary people had seized control of the direction of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman and her child lighting candles Wednesday in memory of protesters killed in recent clashes with the police in Kiev.

item.title: Warlords With Dark Pasts Battle in Afghan Election
item.description: Six of the 11 presidential tickets in Afghanistan include at least one candidate viewed as a warlord, complicating U.S. efforts to get the next administration to sign a long-term security deal.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys in Kabul fixed a tire below a billboard for the presidential campaign of Ashraf Ghani.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Journalists Fear Attack on Hong Kong Editor Won’t Be Solved
item.description: The Hong Kong police have had trouble trying to solve previous attacks on local journalists or media executives, and now they face a very high-profile case.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A police officer interviewing a relative of Kevin Lau Chun-to at the hospital where the journalist was being treated.

item.title: Letter from India: Questioning a Rising Star's Exoneration
item.description: A book accuses investigators in the 2002 Gujarat riots of going to great lengths to shield Narendra Modi and of ignoring disturbing circumstantial evidence.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Steel Mill Closes, Guangzhou Loses a Piece of Its History
item.description: The Guangzhou Steel factory, formerly a small, semi-independent city of its own, with 6,000 workers, has largely fallen silent.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Staircases rusting away at what remains of the Guangzhou Steel mill, ordered shut down in 2010.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Beijing, Complaints About Smog Grow Louder and Retaliation Grows Swifter
item.description: Anger is rising over the government’s inability to protect the nation from pollution that has made places like the capital “unsuitable for human habitation,” as a prominent think tank stated this month in a study that was swiftly censored.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Visitors are silhouetted against thick smog at Jingshan Park near the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pushing for a Law Against Domestic Violence in China
item.description: Feminists have been campaigning for a comprehensive law against domestic violence in China for nearly 15 years. The National People’s Congress meeting next week may be an opportunity to push the agenda forward.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Women demonstrating against domestic violence in Beijing on Feb. 14, 2012. The posters say, from left, "Love is no excuse for violence," "Only equality is harmonious; violence is not a special zone" and "When violence is around, are you still silent?"

item.title: Policy Makers Devise Plans to Provide Money to Kiev
item.description: Substantial assistance from the International Monetary Fund, the United States and others would come after a transitional government is in place in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Currency exchange rates are posted in Kiev as Ukraine seeks to recover from political turmoil.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Editor Whose Ouster Stirred Protests Is Slashed
item.description: The slashing of the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper comes just a month after he was dismissed from a job in which he oversaw reporting that was critical of the mainland Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A police officer standing by the car of Kevin Lau, the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper who was stabbed Wednesday.

item.title: As Putin Orders Drills in Crimea, Protesters’ Clash Shows Region’s Divide
item.description: The new government in Kiev is faced with the challenge of calming separatism at home while placating President Vladimir V. Putin, who sees Ukraine as a vital part of his strategy to rebuild Russian influence.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rival protesters clashed in Simferopol, Crimea’s regional capital.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: College Attack Death Toll Rises
item.description: The United Nations reported Wednesday that at least 45 students were killed in the attack by Islamic extremists on a college in Nigeria this week and that the victims were as young as 13.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Group to Seek House Arrest for Navalny
item.description: Russia’s powerful Investigative Committee said Wednesday that it would ask a court to put Aleksei A. Navalny, an opposition politician, under house arrest.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Venezuela Accuses Intelligence Officers of Murdering 2
item.description: The Venezuelan national prosecutor accused seven intelligence service members of killing a demonstrator and a government supporter after a protest.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yeferson Mayorca, 16, after lung surgery at a hospital in San Cristóbal on Wednesday. Relatives said security forces shot him.

item.title: Disbelief After Egypt Announces Cures for AIDS and Hepatitis C
item.description: The army doctor who announced the cures said they were the result of years of his own study. At some point, he said, military intelligence had taken on his research as a secret project.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Civilians Flee as Violence Worsens in South Sudan
item.description: One month after a cease-fire was signed, residents and aid groups say they had increasingly become victims of the warring sides, who attack homes and hospitals alike.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Doctors Without Borders, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph from Doctors Without Borders, from Sunday, of its burned-out medical storage area in Leer, South Sudan.
